content: Okay, so I remade the issue labels and labeled the issues as needed
There's now a "need triage" label specifically to mark for discussion (somewhat parallel to rustc's nominated)
In particular, I've marked 7 of them under this
I'll go through them and explain why. This is mostly for @nikomatsakis to respond as needed, but also if anyone else has comments
inference, lazy normalization, and occurs check. This is 3 years old at this point. Nothing actionable and relevant FIXMEs are no longer there. Should we close or identify something actionable
Elaborating where clauses on traits, structs. Similar, 3 years old. Really not sure what to do with this.

README doesn't make it clear exactly what chalk is. I think this one is probably closable. I definitely want to go through the README and clean up a bit, but there isn't really anything actionable here. It also is supplemented by the book.
support "specialized" impls. @Aaron Hill also asked about this status. Anything left to do here that isn't covered more generally by https://github.com/rust-lang/chalk/issues/9?
refine RustIrDatabase interface. Is there more design work to do here? Seems like the branch you link is merged?

make chalk inner loop "fuel friendly". I think this one is "done" with the changes in https://github.com/rust-lang/chalk/pull/321. I think that I should open up a follow up issue though with some improvements I want to make to solve_limited. I'm curious what you mean when you mean floundering and cycles do an unbounded amount of work. (cycle somewhat I know, but not entirely)

extract rustc-guide content to make a chalk book. So, we obviously have a book. It's incomplete, so maybe we use this as a tracking issue. The only thing I think still relevant with this is mentioning CHALK_DEBUG and reading list, though I think we have places for those
And that's everything
@nikomatsakis if you could dedicate a bit of time to at least go through each of these and decide if they can/should be closed, or clarify what needs to be done going forward that would be nice :)
I will try to do that today and if not today then Friday
but I think I can do that today :)
/me adds to daily to do list
It's not super urgent. But I figured a bit of a ping would be helpful
OK let me get to this finaklly

Jack Huey said:

inference, lazy normalization, and occurs check. This is 3 years old at this point. Nothing actionable and relevant FIXMEs are no longer there. Should we close or identify something actionable

I think we should just close this. There may be a relevant problem that arises as we push further through, but let's wait till we have some concrete examples of the problem.

Jack Huey said:

Elaborating where clauses on traits, structs. Similar, 3 years old. Really not sure what to do with this.

to some extent we "implemented" this -- the lowering rules include elaboration and implied bounds. I do think there is some problem here in that the rules chalk implements are different (arguably better, but still) than what rustc does. They are really implementing the rules from rfc#2089
Still, I think we should close this particular issue
I sort of think though that the "concept" of aligning this stuff should move into the "skill-tree"
I think a lot of these "higher-level" things ought to move there instead, issues should be for more immediately actionable things
Pinging @nikomatsakis. When you get some time, can you go through the rest of the issues labeled "needs triage" and either close or comment on them? Thanks <3
Hey @Jack Huey I have a question here
There are a number of "longer term" chalk goals
e.g., modeling specialization or whatever
that are represented above
I would like some place to link to from the skill-tree
that gives thoughts and details
but I wonder if it'd be beter to close the issues
and open wiki pages
I don't think that the issue format is especially helpful, in that it encourages "conversation" (which I think is better kept consolidated here, on Zulip)
I think that if the topics of the issues are relevant and have a "goal" or some actionable item, then they can stay open/linked
I also don't know how useful it is to have issues open purely for discussion
Or have an issue open if there's not a clear way to close it
what do you think about using wiki as a place to "collect" constraints, ideas, and drafts?
an alternative might be to add files into wg-traits
we've generally been kind of "anti-wiki"
but I feel like this is a place where they might be a good fit

nikomatsakis said:

we've generally been kind of "anti-wiki"

I think some of the reasons are: they generally become outdated, hard to manage changes and proposed changes (in contrast to PRs)
weird licensing problems
Can you be more specific about what you would expect to be added to the wiki? (or as files)
It would be nice to consolidate/link the numerous Hackmd/paper docs
but I'm not sure if that's what you mean
As far as the wiki, I'm not sure I'm against it. But I can imagine it would get out of date. And would just end up being "just another thing to keep updated and manage"
It would be good to think about what kind of "workflow" we want to have as idea/problems come in and code goes out
(and the bug reports/additional problems repeat the cycle)

Jack Huey said:

As far as the wiki, I'm not sure I'm against it. But I can imagine it would get out of date. And would just end up being "just another thing to keep updated and manage"

Right, like there's also the GH projects thing we don't use too much

Jack Huey said:

Can you be more specific about what you would expect to be added to the wiki? (or as files)

Yes! I'm thinking of design notes on things like specialization, specifically, and other longer-term goals.
I feel like there is useful info that should be captured.
Some of which currently lives in the issues.
But issues don't seem to be the best place to capture that sort of thing.
One interesting bit of this is that I think content like that doesn't get out of date as quickly,
as it tends to involve more "fundamental concepts"
the notation may be old, but the problems are often still quite relevant
That said, I think another relevant case would be something like #wg-traits > extracting examples from chalk
So, I guess this is split into a few parts as to how I feel about where things should go:

1) Design "planning" conversations should probably primarily occur on Zulip. Or issues if people that aren't on Zulip decide to be involved (but I think this will be rare and really should be discouraged). Once we have a "plan", then things get typed up into a Hackmd and Paper doc, and maybe added to the skill tree. A link to these "living documents" can be posted to some combination of the issue, zulip thread, skill tree, wg-trait project, or maybe as a file, such as like an RFC almost. When a feature is "complete", the design docs could be uploaded verbatim to the wg-traits repo for posterity if we want.
2) When something is "decided" or "finished", a relevant chapter of the books (either Chalk or rustc) should be updated to reflect the current state
3) The "examples" I think could be uploaded as "programs" either as test in the Chalk repo or as a file in wg-traits repo

Jack Huey said:

...the issue, zulip thread, skill tree, wg-trait project, or maybe as a file, such as like an RFC almost...

maybe I should elaborate on what I feel the benefits/disadvantages of each are

• Issues I feel are most useful when there is a "actionable goal", specifically something that could, theoretically, be closed with a pull request (but not always). So, an obvious example of this is https://github.com/rust-lang/chalk/issues/341. It's a very discrete type of goal, with a clear endpoint. A less obvious example of this would be https://github.com/rust-lang/chalk/issues/318. This one doesn't necesarily have a clear endpoint (since it really stems from an observation from invalid state). But it does have reproduction steps (even though they are a bit outdated because we no longer truncate). Nevertheless, it remains something that can be investigated. But is also (because we don't truncate anymore), I wouldn't be upset if it was closed. Another example of issue that we don't really have right now, but I think is also ok is a "tracking issue" (e.g. rustc integration). The obvious endpoint would be rustc using Chalk as the trait solver. In general, issues are a good place to briefly summarize mentoring guidelines, progress, and a "list" of things to do. And this is doubly so since that's generally the first place people go to look if they "want to get involved".

• Zulip threads are great for discussion, both sync and async. But they don't seem to be good for posterity (sure, you can permalink to a thread, but searching topics, especially older, is probably not great).
• The skill tree is super useful as an organizational tool (and super cool in general), but you can't add a ton of information to it, by itself
• wg-trait projects can be nice for organization too, but I actually think the skill tree supersedes most of the useful functionality
• wg-trait files are good for posterity and "mostly static" things, but I don't think is great for "living documents"

• Hackmd and paper docs are really good for summarizes discussions, topics, or ideas into an organized, readable doc. They're great for "putting on paper" thoughts. The big downside (if anything) is just keeping track of them. And I don't think they would be useful as an "ever-growing" document
But anyways, those are just my thoughts :)

@Jack Huey I think I'm in between. For larger design efforts, I don't think they can exist on zulip alone. I think it's very useful to have write-ups and drafts for things like that. Otherwise people have to read all the conversation and it's impossible to "catch up" (I think this same problem is part of the reason that issues are not a good fit.)

I think I'd like to see wg-traits as a repo that can collect such documents. That said, I agree that hackmd + paper is also a nice medium and maybe just better than a wiki. That said, I do remember that when we were working on "implied bounds", we went through a number of varieties, and I wish we had can been keeping a "implied_bounds" directory with drafts and design notes from those various points.
